channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-10521] Compiler complains about abstract method not implemented when implementing trait
item.description:
I have a trait called ProviderAssertions that is successfully implemented by a number of spock.lang.Specification types. However, when compiling this class with Groovy 4.0.1-SNAPSHOT:

It fails with the following error:

:model-core:compileTestGroovy FAILED	
Note: Some input files use or override a deprecated API.	
Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details.	
Note: /Users/lptr/Workspace/gradle/gradle/subprojects/model-core/src/test/groovy/org/gradle/internal/instantiation/generator/AsmBackedClassGeneratorTest.java uses unchecked or unsafe operations.	
Note: Recompile with -Xlint:unchecked for details.	
startup failed:	
/Users/lptr/Workspace/gradle/gradle/subprojects/model-core/src/test/groovy/org/gradle/api/internal/provider/DefaultProviderFactoryTest.groovy: 27: Can't have an abstract method in a non-abstract class. The class 'org.gradle.api.internal.provider.DefaultProviderFactoryTest' must be declared abstract or the method 'void assertHasProducer(org.gradle.api.internal.provider.ProviderInternal, org.gradle.api.Task, org.gradle.api.Task[])' must be implemented.	
 @ line 27, column 1.	
   class DefaultProviderFactoryTest extends Specification implements ProviderAssertions {	
   ^	
1 error

https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/c692f2a1d2baa03f975c443ddc746d885cf84ee2/subprojects/model-core/src/test/groovy/org/gradle/api/internal/provider/DefaultProviderFactoryTest.groovy#L27

https://ge.gradle.org/s/mz3m6drw3kzog/console-log?task=:model-core:compileTestGroovy

The same code works with Groovy 3.0.9, and it even compiled with Groovy 4.0.0-beta-1.
item.summary: Compiler complains about abstract method not implemented when implementing trait

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I wonder if the problem has something to do with the fact that the error message says the missing method is:

void assertHasProducer(org.gradle.api.internal.provider.ProviderInternal, org.gradle.api.Task, org.gradle.api.Task[])

But the method the trait declares has varargs Task arguments.

...and if that's a problem somehow, why isn't it triggered in all the other types implementing the same trait?

It does compile if I unroll `assertHasProducer()` like this:


    void assertHasProducer(ProviderInternal<?> provider, Task task1) {
        assertHasProducer(provider, [task1])
    }

    void assertHasProducer(ProviderInternal<?> provider, Task task1, Task task2) {
        assertHasProducer(provider, [task1, task2])
    }

    void assertHasProducer(ProviderInternal<?> provider, Task task1, Task task2, Task task3) {
        assertHasProducer(provider, [task1, task2, task3])
    }

    void assertHasProducer(ProviderInternal<?> provider, List<Task> expected) {
        def producer = provider.producer
        assert producer.known
        def tasks = []
        producer.visitProducerTasks { tasks.add(it) }
        assert tasks == expected
        tasks.clear()
        producer.visitContentProducerTasks { tasks.add(it) }
        assert tasks == expected
    }

test case: https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/750172d5728b313affebc3858a41618623b8168f

let me know if I missed anything
Do I understand correctly that you can reproduce the problem? If so, when can we expect a fix? This is stopping Gradle's adoption of Groovy 4. Thanks!
This test case compiles with no errors.

It is possible that the last parameter of the method when loaded via a class may use [Lorg.gradle.api.Task; format and the class being compiled has org.gradle.api.Task[]. Although ClassNode#equals was recently updated to account for this.

org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.ClassCompletionVerifier#checkNoAbstractMethodsNonabstractClass is where this error is produced. You could set a breakpoint on the line where addError is called and then remote debug your process.

I tried setting groovyVersion to 4.0.0, 4.0.1 and 4.0.2-SNAPSHOT in gradle/build-logic/build-platform/build.gradle.kts and "org.codehaus.groovy" to "org.apache.groovy". I was unable to get 4.0.0 to compile but 4.0.1 and 4.0.2 compiled fine and model-core:test completed successfully.

Update: I tried 4.0.3 – which doesn't exist – and it completed successfully so I really can say what is going on.

There was a recent issue with traits and varags being applied ahead of time. This might have helped ProviderAssertions as well.

I can still reproduce this issue with groovy 4.0.5-SNAPSHOT, and created a branch to help reproduce the problem. Steps to reproduce:

0. Prerequisite: JDK 11 on path
1. clone gradle/gradle
2. checkout branch km/groovy-10521
3. $ ./gradlew :model-core:compileTestGroovy
4. See compilation failure mentioned above: https://ge.gradle.org/s/mkw4nkdmxzhqq
5. $ git revert 65f5f47bd473d4d36b46df66b346c8336a3342e0
6. Run step 3 again; success
I’ll try to look at this over the weekend or on Monday. It would be nice to have a smaller recreation project/script.
Thank you - I will spend a bit of time today and try to make a simpler reproducer.

Just a quick note about your last commit:

public class CustomSuiteRunner extends Suite {
    public CustomSuiteRunner(Class<?> klass, RunnerBuilder builder) {
        super(builder, klass, [ATestClass.class, BTestClass.class] as Class<?>[])
    }
}

You can treat the super constructor like a variadic method and call it this way:

public class CustomSuiteRunner extends Suite {
    public CustomSuiteRunner(Class<?> klass, RunnerBuilder builder) {
        super(builder, klass, ATestClass, BTestClass)
    }
}
Thanks, I will try that. It looks much cleaner without the cast.

I get your branch and run "gradlew :model-core:compileTestGroovy" but it does not fail. If you are able to recreate, you can add this to your model-core's build.gradle.kts:

tasks.withType<GroovyCompile> {
    groovyOptions.setFork(false)
}

Then you can run with -Dorg.gradle.debug=true on your command line and attach to the build process on port 5005. A breakpoint in ClassCompletionVerifier#checkNoAbstractMethodsNonabstractClass should give us a chance to see what the state of the compiler is when it issues the abstract method error. I suspect the ProviderAssertions trait has a method with [Lorg.gradle.api.Task; style signature for the last parameter. Or the test class didn't get an array created for the last parameter. Hard to tell without a failing build.

Update: I did not see that ProviderAssertions already had a workaround on that branch. Rolled that change back and the build fails as expected.

So here are the two methods. As I suspected, the [Lorg.gradle.api.Task; is at play.

MethodNode@413e03b[void assertHasProducer(org.gradle.api.internal.provider.ProviderInternal, org.gradle.api.Task, org.gradle.api.Task[]) from org.gradle.api.internal.provider.ProviderAssertions]

MethodNode@256751a5[void assertHasProducer(org.gradle.api.internal.provider.ProviderInternal, org.gradle.api.Task, [Lorg.gradle.api.Task;) from org.gradle.api.internal.provider.DefaultProviderFactoryTest]

For these to support proper override semantics in ClassNode#getDeclaredMethodsMap the method descriptors need to be the same. This is implemented by MethodNodeUtils#methodDescriptor.
Thank you emilles - is a 4.0.5-SNAPSHOT build with this fix available yet?

Each build pushes a snapshot: https://github.com/apache/groovy/actions/runs/2912982184

I don't know when the snapshot is published to groovy.jfrog.io or if that practice has changed.
I was able to build successfully this afternoon.

Snapshots for 4+ are in the Apache snapshot repo:
https://groovy.apache.org/snapshots.html

Snapshots for versions up to and including 3.x (and mirrors of non-snapshot releases for all versions) are in the groovy.jfrog.io repo.
